Questions.QuestionString: 72. What modulation is used for the beams of a localiser in an ILS?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 150 Hz right of runway centerline, 90 Hz left of runway centreline.
B. 90 Hz below the glide path, 150 Hz above the glide path.
C. 150 Hz left of runway centerline, 90 Hz right of runway centreline.

73. In what frequency range does the automatic direction finding (ADF) system operate?.

74. How does an aircraft distinguish its own Distance Measuring Equipment reply from
those for other aircraft?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. By changing at random the time delay between the pulse pairs of the interrogation signal.
B. By modulation of an audio tone.
C. By using an alternate frequency.

Questions.QuestionString:
75. From where is bearing information received for display on the digital-distance radio
magnetic indicator (DDRMI)?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. From VOR and ADF systems.

77. Why is an aerial tuning unit used in a high frequency (HF) communication system?.
(Level 1)
Answers: A. To extend or retract the aerial and so vary its physical length.
B. To electrically lengthen or shorten the aerial for optimum matching of impedance.
C. To select the transmission/reception frequency in the HF band.

79. What would be the purpose of an input from an inertial reference system being
connected to a weather radar?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. To place the weather radar target in azimuth and distance for the display.
B. To ensure that there is no radar transmission with aircraft on ground.
C. To provide stabilisation for the radar antenna.

81. The Time Reference Scanning Beam (TRSB) corresponds to ILS localiser and glidepath.
How does it operate?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. It operates in the same manner as ILS but utilises higher frequencies.

B. Azimuth and elevation transmitters produce a narrow beam which is rapidly scanned TO
and FRO or UP and DOWN.
C. It operates in conjunction with DME at lower frequencies than ILS.
